awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Chaotic transport -- from fundamental theory to applications in atomic physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Nonlinear dynamics has historically played a fundamental role in explaining diverse and
complex atomic processes, a role which in turn has stimulated numerous theoretical
advances in classical and quantum chaos. This trend continues as advances in atomic
and optical techniques provide an unprecedented level of control and precision for
experimental studies of chaos in atomic systems. For example, the time evolution of
highly localized initial states (e.g. ultrashort optical pulses, Rydberg wavepackets, and
localized ensembles of ultracold atoms), can be measured as they evolve and disperse
within a chaotic potential, thereby probing the detailed fractal structure in the chaotic
phase space. Such precision tools, however, highlight a fundamental deficiency in
theoretical nonlinear dynamics; there exists no general framework (in the sense of
symbolic dynamics) capable of classifying the diversity of chaotic behavior exhibited by
transport in real physical systems.
The focus of this proposal is twofold: (i) It will exploit new advances in chaotic dynamics
to motivate, guide, and interpret experiments capable of probing chaotic phase space
with unprecedented resolution. These include the chaotic transport, ionization, and
control of Rydberg wavepackets as well as the elucidation of novel chaotic pathways for
the mixing and loss of ultracold atoms in optical traps. (ii) It will develop a nonlinear
dynamics toolbox that can extract an accurate (symbolic dynamics) model for the
structure of chaotic transport in Hamiltonian systems with two degrees of freedom. This
model can be made arbitrarily precise, even for systems exhibiting a mixture of chaos
and regularity. The prior success of ?homotopic lobe dynamics? in describing phase
space transport will serve as a key ingredient of this program. Finally, recognizing the
natural topological extension of homotopic lobe dynamics to higher dimensional spaces,
this proposal will address the challenge of chaotic transport in more than two degrees of
freedom, for which far fewer techniques currently exist.

Classifying chaotic trajectories

Regular, well-behaved mechanical systems are epitomized by the
periodic motion of the planets or the regular ticking of a pendulum
clock.  However, most mechanical systems are not regular, but are
chaotic, having wild and unpredictable trajectories.  Such chaotic
systems exist on the scale of our solar system (asteroid dynamics)
down to the scale of atoms (electron dynamics).  Much is still unknown
about such systems, including a general technique to classify the
varied behaviors chaotic trajectories may exhibit.

One of the main successes of this project was the development and
implementation of a technique for classifying chaotic trajectories in
systems with two degrees of freedom; such systems include, for
example, the motion of an atomic electron in applied electric and
magnetic fields.  These two-degree-of-freedom systems are difficult to
characterize, in part, because their motion can be both chaotic or
regular, depending on the initial conditions of the system.  We
developed a theoretical foundation (called homotopic lobe dynamics) to
classify such trajectories through symbolic labeling.  We also devised
a way to partition a system's behavior into qualitatively distinct
states.  Finally, we developed a computational toolbox (in Matlab)
that automates this classification and partitioning scheme on the
computer.  One application that this toolbox can achieve is the
labeling and computation of periodic motion of chaotic systems.  Such
periodic motion is the starting point for numerous applications in
dynamical systems theory and in quantum mechanics.

Turnstile ionization: theory and experiments

Under appropriate conditions, the ionization of an atom occurs via
chaotic dynamics.  Such conditions occur, for example, when a highly
excited atom is subjected to a series of electromagnetic pulses.  We
proposed, and theoretically demonstrated, that this ionization would
occur via a chaotic mechanism called a "phase space turnstile".  The
turnstile is, in essence, a kind of "trap door" that promotes an
electron from a bound to an unbound state.  Collaborating with the
atomic research laboratory of Barry Dunning at Rice University, we
demonstrated that this turnstile mechanism can be seen experimentally
in real potassium atoms.  The turnstile geometry was clearly imprinted
on the time-dependence of the ionization behavior.  Importantly, this
means that by tailoring the turnstile geometry, one can exert control
over the ionization process.

Escape of Bose-Einstein condensates from a chaotic trap

In collaboration with Boaz Ilan, we numerically studied the escape of
a small cloud of ultra-cold (technically, Bose-condensed) atoms from a
chaotic trap.  The atomic cloud sloshed around in the trap, exhibiting
the expected chaotic behavior.  Since the trap had a "hole" in it,
some atoms would leak out, creating a very complex time-dependence to
the leakage.  We saw fractal structure in this time-dependence, as
well as quantum interference effects.  (Fractals are geometric
patterns with detailed, fine-scale structure visible at all levels of
resolution as one zooms in on the pattern.)  Importantly, we found
that attractive interactions between the atoms not only suppressed the
quantum interference but also enhanced the fractal resolution.

Reaction fronts in fluid flows

The chaotic dynamics seen in atomic systems is a general phenomenon
seen in many other systems, including the motion of fluids like water;
this is an indication of the interconnected nature of nonlinear
dynamics.  In this spirit, our study of chaos in atomic systems led to
a study of chaos in the dynamics of reaction fronts growing outward
within a flowing fluid.  This work was inspired by a collaboration
with Tom Solomon, an experimental physicist at Bucknell University.
